div.head: AERIAL WARFARE POSSIBILITIES
div.p: France, which built the first ironclad and led the way in the cycle trade and the motorcar industry, is also ahead in "conquest of the air," though "paced" apparently by America. Already people other than pessimistic poets begin to see visions of "aerial navies battling in the central blue." On the occasion of the great military review in Paris last week, the cigar shaped airship "La Patrie'' successfully executed a scries of manœuvres in mid-air. Further testimony of the dirigible qualities of the "Patrie" was afforded on July 22, when the Premier, M. Clemenceau, and the Minister for War, General Picquart, made an ascent and manoeuvred about over the city of Paris for several hours. In a subsequent interview M. Clemenceau said that he was very favourably impressed by the wonderful sense of stability he experienced during the trip. "One could not have felt more safe on the deck of a greet liner," he said. "We descended, and so gently did the marvellous machine alight that we did not know we had touched earth again until we were told so."

According to the Paris correspondent of the "Daily Chronicle," several new dirigibles on the model of the "Patrie" are being constructed forthwith, and M. Julliot, the engineer of Messrs. Lebaudy Bross., and designer of the "Patrie," counts upon introducing many improvements in the new airship. A sum of £12,000 now remains on the estimates for the building of the new ship, but the military commission is to ask Parliament for a fresh credit. Although the "Lebaudy" was purchased for £4,000, the "Patrie" cost £14,000, and this is to be the sum paid for the additional ships. M. Julliot is certain that the "Patrie'' and airships of her class will play an important part in the land war of the future. They would, he points out, be of inestimable value to the commander of a besieged garrison. It is next to impossible for artillery to hit a sphericalshaped mass fifty metres long travelling at forty kilometres an hour at an altitude of 10 0 metres.

A story of how Germany has been trying to discover the secret of the construction of the "Patrie" is published in the "Petit Parisien" and quoted in the "Times." A company was founded last year in Germany for the study of aerial navigation. Its manager, Herr von Kehler, jonrneyed to Paris in September last to ask M. Julliot if he could construct "for sporting purposes" a steerable balloon, like the one made by him for MM. Lebaudy. He offered 1,000,000 marks (£50,000). M. Julliot induced Herr von Kehler to write to MM. Lebaudy, who replied on the morrow : "We have to inform you that we cannot, to our great regret, construct the steerable balloon that you desire."

The rebuff was what was to be expected, but Germany did not abandon the hope of securing the balloon by purchase, as certain facts which may ultimately become known will prove. But, meanwhile, she is trying to copy the French war balloon from such data as are already common property. Whether she will succed is another matter, for while the general principles of construction are well known, the delicate calculations concerning essential relations between parts of the machine remain M. Julliot's secret. If France, therefore, resolutely continues to construct a fleet of airships on his model it will be difficult for any Power, even supposing the right formula be found, to catch up with her. For as was indicated in the Paris correspondence of the "Times," the training of the crews is, perhaps, more than half the problem. The cigar shaped war ballon with which the German authorities are experimenting made a successful ascent on July 23 from the depot in Jungfernbeide, between Charlottenburg, and Spandau. During a cruise of over three hours it appeared readily to answer the helm.

div.head: The Brindisi Mall.
div.p: The mail from Europe via Brindisi and Port Said (P. and 0.) will be diatributed at the Alexandria Post Office at half past four this afternoon.

div.head: Fire at Gabbari.
div.p: As we go to press we are informed by telephone that a big fire is raging in some stores at Gabbari, but owing to the late hour at which we receive the news no details are available.

div.head: Libel Case.
div.p: Mr. Cuinenos, proprietor of the newspaper "Le Bospore," has been condemmed by the Hellenic Consular Tribunal to six months' imprisonment and a fine of 2,000 francs for libel against Mr. Tambacopoulo.

div.head: Cairo Drinking Water.
div.p: Dr. Hussein Eff. Yousri, of Cairo has sent cards of invitation to his confrères calling them to à meeting at his house on Friday 9th inst. to discuss tlio properties of the drinking water of the Artesian Wells.

div.head: Pollos Budget.
div.p: During the last 24 hours, 9 thefts, 9 misdemeanours and 41 contraventions were reported in Cairo and its suburbs against 4 thefts, 14 misdemeanours and 51 contraventions recorded during the preceding 24 hours.

div.head: Cutting thr Khalig.
div.p: The official ceremony of cutting the Khalig will take place at Foum-el-Khalig, Old Cairo, on the evening of the 24th instant, with the customary formalities and fête. All Government offices will be closed on the 25th instant.

div.head: Quarantine Board.
div.p: The monthly meeting of the Quarantine was held yesterday under the presidency of Dr. Ruffer. Four new members were elected to the Permanent Commiasion, and the question of the importation of cattle from Servia received considerable attention. Dr. Ruffer and Mr. de Courcy have left for Tor.

div.head: Crime in the Provinces.
div.p: Farag Hendaoui, a native of the village of Nahir-el-Massourea, was endeavouring to light a fire on his roof, when an Albanian guard in the service of Prince Kamel-el-Dine became so enraged at the native's refusal to put out the fire that he drew his revolver and shot him dead. The murderer was immediately arrested.

div.head: Murder of an Omdeh.
div.p: Omar Abit, Omdeh of the village of Touh, was killed while inspecting his property. A shot was fired by a unknown person concealed among the cotton bushes. The servants of the Omdeh hurried to the spot on hearing the report of the gun, only to find their master dead. The police consider it an act of vengeance.

div.head: Theatre des Ambassadeurs.
div.p: A gala performance will be given this evening at the Théâtre des Ambassadeurs on the occasion of the début of "La Belle Andalouse," who is the leading dancer of the Theatre Royal at Madrid. The performance is timed to start at 9.30 and a complete change of programme and reduction in prices of admission has been made.

div.head: Police Libel Case.
div.p: The action brought by tho Mamour of Karmouz district against the three Arabic organs "Al Mokattam", "Al-Watan," and "Al Shark," came before the Cairo Summary Tribunal this morning. Hopkinson Bey has gone to Cairo to give evidence, and Mustapha Bey Fahmy has been elected president of the court. Attia Bey Hussein conducted the prosecution. The damages claimed are $3,000.

div.head: Tram Accidents.
div.p: Yesterday morning, at 10 o'clock, while attempting to mount a tram in Sharia Clot Bey, Dr. Mohamed Eff. Nached was run into by another tram coming from Rod el Farag and received such injuries to both legs that two month's treatment in hospital will be necessary. A native woman, named Farida, was also knocked down by a tram at Shoubra and very severely injured, having three ribs broken. Procès-verbaux have been drawn up against the wattmans.

div.head: Plague.
div.p: During the week ending the 5th instant, 15 cases of plague were recorded throughout Egypt, of which 13 were reported from Alexandria, 1 at Dainanbour, atid 1 at Minieh. From the beginning of the year up to the 5th August, 1043 cases of bubonic plague were registered, as against 404 reoorded during the corresponding period of last year. 1 admission to, 1 death outside and 2 deaths in hospital at Alexandria were the only cases registered during the past 24 hours. 14 patients still remain under treatment.

div.head:
THE YEMEN TROUBLE.
TURKISH TROOPS AT HODEIDA
ACTIVITY OF THE REBELS
div.p: (From Our Own Correspondent).
Aden, July 29.

Advices from Hodeida state that a batch of about 1,500 Turkish time-expired troops have arrived there from Sana and other places for embarkation to their homes. They waited there for some days but no transport steamer was provided for them. As usual these discontented soldier have grown weary and are giving great trouble to the people At Hodeida. They looted the shops and houses of the natives, and had a fight with the latter, in which about 30 casualties have occurred. The natives have been closing their shops for several days.

A few days previous to this, another batch of Turkish time-expired troops proceeded to Hodeida for embarkation, and similarly looted the goods of the natives, and several casualties occurred, and when they embarked they had a fight amongst themselves on board the ship. It seems inexplicable why such desperate troops should be let loose upon the natives before a transport ship is arranged for, and there is no reason why a steamer should not be chartered or a transport-ship brought to be ready for the day of the troops arrival, for such occurrences are having disastrous moral effect.
News has reached Hodeida from Constantinople regarding the appointment of General Raggeb Pasha as Military Commander in Yemen, but the appointment, has not yet been officially announced.
It is reported that some Bedouins from the interior of Hodeida attacked a house in Hodeida, and killed one of the inmates of the house and plundered the property.
Aden, August 1.

Advices from Yemen state that the rebels have occupied several places and strong positions lying between Hodeida and Sana. One of these places is Mullian, a strong position about 2 days'journey northeast of Hodeida, and not garrisonod but is rulod . by a Sheikh. It was taken without resistance by the inhabitants.

Another place captured by the rebels is Hatasli which liés about the same distance from Hodeida as Mulhan. It is divided from Mulhan by a valley, and is not garrisoned by Turkish troops. It was also taken without fighting.

The rebels attacked Al Muhwait, a Turkish coffee-growing centre lying about 3 days' journey from Hodeida. This district is inhabited by a comparatively industrious people. The rebels plundered the inhabitants and captured a number of them and conveyed them to the Imam.

A desperate body of the rebels under Ibn Hoobaish, who comes from the district of Al Muhwait, and who has recently joined the standard of the Imam, attacked Beni Kais, a district about one day's journey North-East of Hodeida, and ruled by an Arab, Abdulla Pasha Al Boani, who is under the protection of the Turks. The rebels had an engagement with Al Boani, in which the latter last about 40.
Anis, a Turkish district lyving about two days' journey from Sana and not garrisoned by Turkish troops, has been captured by the rebels without resistance from the inhabitants.
Later advices from Hodeida state that the Turkish time-expired troops had another fight with the natives, in which about six casualties of the former, and about five of the latter have occurred.

div.head: WEATHER OF JULY
div.p: The following report on the weather of last month has been issued by the Survey Department:-

As is usually the case at this time of the year, there has been but little variation from day to day in the weather. Normal conditions have been maintained over the Eastern Mediterranean, there being a steady gradient towards the East over the sea and over Egypt.

In the Sudan, the summer depression which is probably connected with that of Northwestern India in the monsoon season, has been fully developed in the neighbourhood of Suakin, causing the usual southerly and southwesterly winds in the Sudan.
Atmospheric pressure was above normal in Egypt but slightly below in the Sudan. Mean temperature was slightly below the normal value everywhere except at Merowe and El Obeid.

The rains, which had been weak in June, shewed but little improvement in July, and, except at a few stations, the total fall was considerably below the average. Ort the whole, this deficiency on the Abyssinian tableland seems to have amounted to about 38 per cent, but during the last few days there has been an improvement which is reported to extend to the Arabian Sea and Northwest India.

div.head: DREDGERS FOR SHANGHAI
div.p: SUEZ, Tuesday.

Yesterday forenoon two huge Dutch dredgers the "Colonnia" and "Schelde," came out of the Canal towed by the tugs "Thames" and "Rhenia." These dredgers are bound to Shanghai, but owing to one of the tugs having broken 3 blades of her propeller in the Canal, their departure has been postponed till repairs are completed.

div.head:
THE BANDMANN FOLLIES.
AN EXCELLENT COMBINATION
div.p: Cairo, Monday. It is seldon, indeed, that members of the British community in Cairo meet in such large numbers, as was the case to-night in the Abbas Theatre on the occasion. of the first performance of Mr. Bandmann's new troupe "The Follies," and the extent of the attendance was as surprising to the audience itself, unhappily accustomed to half empty theatres, as the packed house must have been gratifying to the actors and actresses. From an early hour on Monday evening the doors of the theatre were eagerly besieged by a crowd, who it was evident had omitted to reserve their seats beforehand, and shortly before the curtain was timed to rise an altogether exceptionally influx of people blocked the gangways. Fortunately the building is a large one and everyone eventually succeeded in finding a place. In short, the attendance was excellent and almost unique for a summer entertainment of this kind.

The words of the opening chorus conveyed a lucid description of the artists' powers, which afterwards were proved to be in no way exaggerated, but the musical rendering offered small promise of the excellent programme, which was in reality to follow. A certain amount of hesitation was noticeable, unison was poor and the general idea given was that rehearsals had been neglected. It is a pity that the very first item should have been so weak, especially as one is inclined to form opinions, however erroneous, from the opening turns. Fortunately, however, this was the only disappointing part of a lengthy and really excellent entertainment. Mr. Villiers Arnold, who is a powerful baritone, gave "Take a Pair of Sparkling Eyes" in an exceedingly pleasing way and there is no doubt that the applause, with which the song was received, was thoroughly earned. In the second part of the programme his song "The Mediterranean" was delivered with even more swing, and Mr. Arnold is to be congratulated upon having an exceptionally melodious voice, which is at the same time clear and strong. Miss Emilie Tait was the next to give us a talented exhibition of her powers, and, though her voice is, perhaps, a trifle small for so large a building as the Abbas Theatre, still the purity of her notes and the sweetness of tone was remarkable, and her encore, "The Pomeranian Dog," is catchy and was enthusiastically applauded. Space does not allow of a very full account of the entertainment and several clever turns must necessarily be overlooked, but mention must be made of Mr. H. Herbert, who is the life and soul of the troupe, and who kept tho house in roars of laughter for many minutes with his witty songs and his killingly funny facial contortions. Neither must Mr. Osborne's ventriloquial sketch be passed over without special comment. The dexterity with which he modified and diminished the sound of the voice and carried the art of illusion to the height of perfection, entitles him to be called a prince of ventriloquists. Again, the accompanist, Mr. G. Stamford, proved himself worthy of attention, despite the fact that in his piano solo he scarcely succeeded in altogether mastering the difficulties of an intricate piece, for he humourously illustrated to us how music may be safely pirated and cleverly manipulated so as to form an original operetta. Miss Florence Beech is a charming and most talented actress, who soon gained the sympathy of the audience by her pretty face and graceful movements.

One noticeable fact of the evening was that the encores were invariably superior to the advertised turn. The musical portion of the programme was followed by a new series of pictures on the London Bioscope which were extremely interesting, although at times somewhat indistinct.

The entertainment is a very enjoyable one, the jokes are fresh and entirely free from any double meaning, a bet which is rare indeed in this country, and, in short, the entire performance is of a high order and is perhaps best described by a remark overheard in the vestibule "It is a white man's show". The standard of excellency attained from a musical point of view is so good that many of Monday night's audience intend to be present at all the subsequent performances, which will be changed each night.
Cairo, Tuesday,

"The Follies" gave another most excellent performance at the Abbas Theatre last night, on the occasion of their second appearance, before an even more enthusiastic audience than that which assisted at the opening entertainment. The programme, which was entirely changed, was, perhaps, superior to the previous night and the artists, who appeared to have somewhat recovered from the fatigues of their recent travels, were in first rate form and are to be heartily thanked for having furnished us with a really most enjoyable evening. Miss Emilie Tait was again greatly applauded, as was also the pianist Mr. Stamford, who demonstrated his perfect mastery over the keys in a most humourous and interesting manner. Encores were frequent and judging from last night's reception the troupe ought to leave our shores well pleased with the welcome which Egypt has accorded them.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Moss liner "Menepthah" sailed from Malta yesterday afternoon and is now due here on Saturday with passengers, mails, and general cargo.
The S.S "Scottish Prince," with passengers and general cargo, left Manchester on the 1st inst., and is due to arrive at Alexandria on or about the 17th inst.

div.head: THE FINANCIAL ADVISERSHIP.
div.p: SIR.V.CORBETT'S SUCCESSOR

Speculating as to the probable successor to Sir Vincent Corbett, "Al Watan" says:- It appears that a vast minority of the Nationalist papers prefer the appointment of Chitty Bey to the post when the present Adviser retires, presumably because that honest and experienced gentleman was known to favour the employment and promotion of individuals of the predominant partner. He is one of the very few Englishmen who are mentioned by the Nationalist papers without acerbity or acrimony. We congratulate Chitty Bey upon this distinction and are with the correspondent of the "Egyptian Gazette" who thinks that he has the best claim for the high position, by virtue of bis former services in the financial departments of the Egyptian Government. But it would be the height of folly to prophecy that Chitty Bey is the next Financial Adviser, as the functions of the post are more diplomatic than financial now that the finances of the country are in the best condition, and that no schemes or special measures are required for meeting deficits or raising new funds. We want no Baring or Goschen now at the Ministry of Finance, thanks to the former workers who have brought our finances to the present state of efficiency almost amounting to perfection. We want a diplomat and a statmesman in the post which is the official link between England and Egypt. The Financial Adviser is practically the deputy and representative of the British Agency before the Egyptian Ministry. He is even numbered among our Ministers, for he is called to meetings and allowed to vote on all questions with them, his vote being considered the wish and the policy of the ruling power. He is at times the British Agency and the Egyptian Government combined inasmuch as he over rules the action of our Cabinet in the name of the British Government.

div.head: COUNCIL OF MINISTERS
div.p: The Council of Ministers decided at yesterday's meeting to grant the rank of Moutamaiz of the second class to Hussein Bey Magdi, en pension, and the second rank to Ibrahim Zeki Bey, and , Ahmed Khairy Bey; and approved of the appointment of Mr. Alexander Orlarovsky as Russian Commissioner of the Public Debt. They also sanctioned the opening a credit of £10,000 for the Ministry of Interior for the bubonic and bovine plague measures and tbe establishment of new cemeteries in Menoufieh, Dakahlieh, and Minieh provinces.

div.head: NORWEGIAN STEAMER AGROUND.
div.p: Suez, Tuesday. The Norwegian steamer "Hiso," bound to Shanghai from Antwerp, is badly aground in the Gulf of Suez, North of Ras Garib lighthouse. This morning a tug with lighters and labour left Suez to go to her assistance

div.head: THE VITRIOL CASE.
div.p: The Belgian Consular Tribunal met yesterday at 5 p.m., under the presidency of the Consul M. Eid assisted by MM. Merzbach and Naus, in order to inquire into the charge against Vittorine Heureux. The evidence of the various witnesses was taken, the most important of which was given by M. Nadel, who gave first aid to the victim, and who heard Vittorine Heureux, cry "He has had what be deserves." Captain Renda said the excited state of the prisoner at the time of arrest, confirmed her words "I am the avenger." Mme Omad at whose house Heureux lodged and worked, said that the prisoner had declared that she had a child whose father was not M. Goldsmith. On the day of the crime she was extremely nervous, and after visiting her son in the hospital had returned in tears, and later on went out, murmuring words of vengeance. She returned at 9 p.m.and wan incoherent in her sleep.

The accused said that the chemist at Shoubrah had refused to sell her the vitriol, and that at length she had stolen some. She affirmed her desire for vengeance and contended that her lover had beaten her.
Counsel for the defence, M. Eddé, has demanded an inquiry into the mental state of Mr. Goldsmith. The Tribunal will meet again on Saturday at 4 p.m.

div.head: CASINO SAN STEFANO
div.p: Noua sommes heureux d'annoncer que samedi soir le 10 aura lieu le grand bal avec "Cotillon", que la direction du Casino offre à ses nombreux abonnés du Club et du Casino. Comme toutes les précédentes, cette fête promet d'être des plus réussies. Les abonnés n'ayant pas encore reçu leur carte d'invitation, sont priés de bien vouloir la réclame au secrétariat du Casino.
Jeudi après-midi nous aurons le plaisir d'entendre un programme tout-a-fait nouveau, tant pour la partie vocale que pour l'instrumentale. Nous en publierons le détail demain.

div.head: AGARD'S INTERNATIONAL INDUSTRIE AND TRADE MARKS REGISTER.-
div.p: a useful business directory containing addresses of all important business firms of Great Britain, the Continent and Egypt, Circulating all over Europe and America. Price- One pound Sterling. Post Free. AGRARD'S INTERNATIONAL HOTEL GUIDE sent port free to all first chain Hotels throughout Europe, America, the Colonies and Egypt. The best reference book for travellers.

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY.
div.p: CRICKET
SHIPPING v. BANKS

Great interest was taken yesterday by the members of the shipping firms and banks of Alexandria, in the cricket match played on the Alexandria cricket ground between teams representing the respective parties, and the pavilion was well crowded with enthusiastic spectators. The match commenced at 2.30 p.m, and the toss being won by Sampson the Banks took first knock. Birch and Inglott went to the wicket first, but Inglott, who played very norvously, soon had his leg stomp displaced by McLean. Inglott shaped well and looked liked getting set, but after three overs he drove a tempter right back to Hobsbaum, who was bowling well on the wicket. Reid had a very short stay with no result, and Roll immediately afterwards fell a victim to a leg-yorker from McLean. Cull, who followed Reid, played very steady and cautions cricket, letting off many balls which should have been punished, but in the long run he and Sampson saved their side from an ignominious defeat. Th^Bfiters of the opening were unchecked until the ninth wicket had fallen, Richards being run out and Merton, Lucke, Barrow, and Martin falling victims to McLean in quick succession. McLean was bowling splendidly and performed the hat trick with the 7th, 8th, and 9th wickets. When Sampson joined Cull, however, a different complexion was put on the game. Nine wickets had fallen for 29 runs but both player, though taking no advantages, got the mastery over the ball, and brought the total up to 112 before Sampson's off stump was displaced by Wellings. Cull's 56 not out was undoubtedly the feature the innings and included 12 boundaries. McLean took 5 wickets for 30 runs, and Hobsbaum 2 for 12, and though Spurgeon took no wickets as a change bowler he kept a good length and kept runs down, but Richley's three overs proved very expensive.

The Shipping team opened very well. Perkins and Harkness immediately got to work, the latterly driving the hall to the boundary frequently, while the former, playing, quietly, made single after single. Both players made the bowling look very simple and 46 was registered before Harkness drove his ball into Birch's hand. Moss then partnered Perkins and immediately took liberties with the bowling, the secend ball which he received being driven straight to the off boundary. With the score at 66 Perkins was out l.b.w. to Sampson, but Wallace, who followed, continued to keep things merry with Moss until the latter's middle stump was displaced by Sampson with the total at 77. Mclean only stopped for one lusty drive to the on boundary and then Wellings kept his end up while Wallace knocked the ball about. The 5th wicket put on 27 but the next only added three, for Merton was put on to bowl underhand lobs and immediately caused a rot, taking 5 wickets for 3 runs, Sampson took 4 wickets for 36 runs. Birch 1 for 33, and Roll 0 for 37.

In their second innings the Banks fared very badly, McLean proving deadly. Two wickets fell before a run had been scored, Birch's middle stump being knocked out of the ground by McLean's first delivery, and the wickets fell in quick succession. Stumps were drawn at half past six with nine wickets down and only 43 runs on the board. McLean came out the with splendid analysis of 7 overs, 3 maidens, 9 runs, 8 wickets, and Wellings took 1 wicket for 10 runs.
Mr. H. Moss was "at home" during the afternoon, tea and light refreshments were served, and the match was greatly enjoytd by both players and spectators.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Sir Reginald Wingate Pasha, 8irder of the Egyptian Army, is expected to return from Europe about the 5th of October next. Hé will stay at Cairo for three weeks in order to prepare, in conjunction with Bernard Pasha, the budget of the Sudan Government, after which will leave for Khartonm.
Sir Horace Pinching will leave on Sunday for England.
Count de Serionne, Superior Agent to the Suez Canal Company in Egypt has left for Europe.
M. Georges Eid, Belgian Consul will sail next Friday for Europe by the Messageries Maritimes mail boat.
Two months' leave of absence has been accorded to Mr. Melville, Inspector of the Ministry of the Interior, dating from 2nd of August with an extension of 16 days at half rate of pay.
Mr. A.W. Hazel, Inspector of the Ministry of the Interior, will return from leave on the 20th inst.

The marriage arranged between Mr. H. R. Day, Egyptian Civil Service, and Margaret Eleanor, eldest daughtor of the Rev. Cecil Mills of Bisterne and Taverham, will take place quietly at Bisterne on the 20th inst.

The marriage of Mr. Kenneth G.V.Murray of the Public Works Department, youngest son of Surgeon Lieut. Col. John Murray, A.M.S (retired), to Muriel H.H Bott, daughter of the late John Bott and Mrs. Bott, formerly of Cheltenham, took place at St. John's Paddington on the 24th ult.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: Le marché a ouvert ce matin ferme et animé. Toute la seance a d'ailleurs été remarquablement tenue, excepté vers la fin on une légère réaction s'est produite à la suite d'offres de vente provenant du Caire. En définitive l'ensemble de la cote est en hausse comme hier, mais comme hier aussi les affaires n'ont pas été nombreuses. Il n'y a pas de vendeurs et l'on comprend que dans de telles circonstances les acheteurs ont beau jeu pour pousser les cours à peu de frais.

En valeurs dirigeantes lé calme prédomine. A part l'Agricole quia donné lieu a quelques transactions, les autres n'ont guère été échangée. L'Agricole s'avance de 8 1/16 à 8 1/8 vendeurs, la National Bank de 19 7/8 à 20, tandis que la Daïra est plus faible à 12 7/8 vendeurs et que la Delta Light revient de 9 15/16 à 9 7/8 et l'Obligation Crédit Foncier de 304 à 303 l'ancienne et de 262 à. 261 vendeurs la nouvelle. L'Agricole et la National Bank, d'abord l'objet d'une demande suivie du Caire, ont été ensuite offertes en clôture.
On a beaucoup remarqué des achats en Land Bank dont le cours progresse de ce fait de 7 3/16 à 7 1/4. La demande provient de Paris.

La demande en Tramways d'Alexandrie, particulièrement en Dividendes, a occasionné une nouvelle reprise sur les cours qui s'avancent de 139 1/2 a 142 1/2 les Privilégiées et de 292 a 300 les Dividendes.
Cette recherche par les marchés étrangers de certaines de nos valeurs entre évidemment en ligne de compte pour l'amélioration constante de notre place depuis une quinzaine de jours.

D'autres valeurs profitent du mouvement: la Cassa di Sconto bénéficie de 5 fr. à 38, la Banque d'Athènes de 1 fr. a 111 1/2, la Deferred Delta de 1/4 de livre à 9 1/2, ainsi que les Nungovich à 13 1/4, le Comptoir de 3/16 l'action à 2 13/16 l'ancienne et 2 3/4 la nouvelle et de 1/4 de livre la part de fondateur a 3, le Crédit Franco-Egyptien de 1/16 à 4 1/8, la Banque d'Orient de 4 fr. à 118 1/2.
L'Alexandria Water fléchit, au contraire, de 11 1/2 à 11 7/16, et l'Urbaine de 3 11/16 à 3 5,8.

Parmi les petites valeurs, la Salt and Soda s'élève de 17/3 a 17/9, les Ritz de 11/16 à 3/4, la Delta Land de 1 3/4 à 1 13/16, et 'a fondateur Allotment de 70 a 50 P.T., tandis que les Cotton Mills faiblissent de 2/6 a 2/, les Sucreries de 35 à 30, et l'Ordinary Khédivial Mail de 22 à 21/9.
Sur le reste de la cote il n'y a pas de chan gements a signaler.

On dit qu'une assez importante maison de courtage et reports du Caire serait sur le point de déposer son bilan. Une maison de courtage d'Alexandrie est également aux prises avec de sérieuses difficultés.

C'est demain que doit avoir lieu le règlement des transactions en Bourse and Banking. On est généralement d'avis que les principaux intéressés dans l'affaire n'ayant pas donné leur consentement à la décision de l'association, le règlement n'aura pas lieu. On se trouvera dans ce cas an même point ou l'on en était avant la décision.

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
div.p: NOTES ET CRITIQUES
Le Caire, Mardi 6 Août
Le taux de l'eseompte libre a Londres se maintient inchangé a 3 3/4 pour cent.
Le Stock Exchange était fermé samedi et lundi à l'occasion du Bank Holiday.
A Paris, le-Crédit Foncier Egyptien a baissé hier de 4 francs à 682. La Banque d'Athènes s'est relevée de 1 franc à 113. Les Lots Turcs ont gagné 2 francs à 169.

Ici, les quelques jours de repos que viept de prendre notre marché lui ont profité, car l'animation déjà fort réjouissante la semaine dernière, a continué aujourd'hui de plus belle ; aussi la cote présente-t-elle une hausse quasi générale sur les valeurs traitées. La confiance un moment ébranlée, parait actuellement tout à fait revenue et l'activité se porte de préférence sur les valeurs locales foncières et immobilières. Les titras des grandee Banques qui, il y a quelques semaines encore, avaient seuls un marché suivi, bien qu'améliorant encore leur position, restent un peu dans l'ombre au profit de valeurs moins lourdes et susceptibles de plus-values considérables eu égard à leur bas prix.
Le projet de rétablissement du marché à terme a exercé aussi une très heureuse influence en ce sens qu'on en attend de bons résultats en faveur de la reprise.
Dans le compartiment des Banques, l'Agricole reste ferme à 8 1/16. La National Bank hansse de l/8 a 20.

Le Crédit Foncier se maintient sans affaires a 687 francs. Les obligations anciennes reculent à 302. L'Allotment réagit légèrement a 2 1/4-5/16 et la fondateur avance à P.T. 60. Les Entreprises Immobilières et Travaux continuent à être très demandées à 1 15/16 en gain de 3/16. Les Héliopolis accentuent leur avance a 247 et leur part à 11 1/2.
Dans le groupe des Hôtels, les Egyptian Hotels (Bachler) haussent de 3/16 à 5 5/16. Les Nungovich se relevent à 13 3/8 et les Ritz finissent a 0 3/4.

Parmi les petites valeur, la Delta Land reste favorisée à 1 3/4-13/16. Les Estates se consolident à 0 11/16 et leur part à 4 3/8. Les New-Egyptian remontent a 14/9 et les Egyptian Constructions à 0 7/16.
Las Bourses du Caire et d'Alexandrie étant fermées hier par suite du chômage des marchés anglais, notre Circulaire n'a pas paru ainsi qu'à l'ordinaire.

Plusieurs de nos lecteurs européens nous ayant demandé si les recentes faillites survenues en Egypte avaient réellement atteint le chiffre de trois millions de livres sterling, comme certains organes de Paris l'ont annoncé, nous saisissons l'occasion de remettre les choses au point.

Ainsi qoe la reprise des valeurs égyptienne" à Londres et fi Paris l'a montré, reprise suivie de stabilité, le marché égyptien n'a jamais été aussi atteint que des correspondante effrayés ont bien voulu /'écrire en Europe. La vérité se résume en offque la orise égyptienne a été pro- voquée par un resserrement. de OTédit qui a forcé quelques spéculateurs fi réaliser leur por- tefeuille. Il s'en est suivi de nouvelles baisses qui ont obligé les détenteurs de titras, trop foibles pour les soutenir, fi les vendre. Cela, et la pénurie monétaire régnante ont amené ia gène dont l'Egypte est actuellement en voie de se libérer. Quant aux défaillances autour desquelles ont a mené grand bruit, elles n'ont en que très peu d'influence sur le marché boursier. Elles ont été uniquement provoquées par le brusque retrait des crédits que les banqueseuropéennos avaient toujours consenties fi quelques ban- ques privées do la place. Au demeurent, d'ailleurs, les maisons visées ont toutes pu s'arranger avec leurs créanciers d'antant plus facilement que leur actif dépas- sait fortement leur passif, qui est en somme peu important Actuellement la situation est redevenue normale et les banques égyptiennes possèdent des quantités considérables de numéraire, de façon fi répondre facilement aux besoins d'ar- gent que fera naître la prochaine campagne cotonnière. * " o Cet après-midi aura lieu une assemblée de la Corporation des agents de cliange aux fins d'examiner la question du marché fi terme et délibérer sur les mesures fi prendre on vue do son rétablissement II est pins que probablo qu'une très forte majorité se prononoera pour l'affirmative. o o Carnet de l'actionnaire. Les actionnaires de la Banque d'Escompto et de Reports d'Egypte ot du Soudan Ltd sont informés que le quatrième etdernier versement sor les actions de oet te Société devra être ef- fectué an plus tard le 24 Août prochain au si*ge social au Caire et à 1A Banque d'Orient fi Alexandrie. " o Une assemblée générale extraordinaire de l'Egyptian Delta Land and Investment Cy Ltd. est convoquée pour le mardi 13 Août oourant fi 6 heures p.m. au siège de la Société au Caire. div.head:
THE CASA BLANCA TROUBLE.
FRENCH TROOPS LAND.
ATTACKED BY MOORS.

div.p: The commander of the "Galilée" demanded and obtained permission to disembark troops to guard the Frenoh Consulate. On landing a number of Moors attacked the troops, wounding seven. The French then charged with the bayonet killing a number of the Moors. At the same time the "Galilé" and "Du Chayla" bombarded the town, their fire being, most efficacious. Some Spaniards took part in the combat. The French occupy the town.
(Havas)
PARIS, August 6.
General Drude will command the French troops at Casablanca.
(Reuter)
TANGIES, August 6.

The French and Spanish men-of-war have arrived and landed a force which was attacked by the Kabyles. Six Frenchmen and one officer have been wounded. After posting guards at the Consulates the ''Galilée'' bombarded the Moorish quarter and surrounding districts.
It is believed that 150 Moors have been killed by the bombardment. (Reuter)

The King and Queen, the Prince and Princess of Wales, and the Duke of Connaught took a trip to sea on board the "Dreadnought." They witnessed the practice with the 12inch guns. Out of 12 shots in three minutes 11 hits were made, 9 of which were ''bulls," at a range of 1 ½ milles : the target was 18 feet square. They afterwards witnessed submarine maneuvuers Above and below the surface. (Reuter)

div.head:
THE SWINEMUNDE MEETING.
PEACE OF THE WORLD.

div.p: Semi-official statements from Berlin and St Petersburg declare that the discussions at Swinemunde covered all the questions of the moment and testified to the desire of both Powers to preserve the peace of world. They have in nowise modified existing alliances, while strengthening Russo-German friendship. Confidence is expressed that Franco-Spanish action in Morocco; in consequence of recent events, will lead, to no complications. They further state that it is recognised that Russo- Japanese convention and the prospective Anglo-Russian agreement was most conducive to the maintenance of general peace. (Reuter)
SWINEMUNDE, August 6.
The Tsar and the German Emperor toasted to the lasting friendship of the two countries. They embraced on separation. (Havas)

div.head:
CHINESE ON THE RAND.
POLICE QUARTERS WRECK.

div.p: 400 Chinese yesterday evening wrecked the Chinese police quarters of the Cason mine and injured 8 police men. 4 Chinese were killed. The riot was eventually quelled. (Reuter)

div.head:
SWIMMING THE CHANNEL.
WOLFEE'S NARROW FAILURE.

div.p: The Channel swimmer Mr. Heaton failed 4 miles from the French coast. Mr. Wolffe also failed within three quarters of a mile. (Reuter)
The Standard Oil Company's stock has not been affected here. It is believed that two years will elapse before the higher courts' decision, is given. (Reuter)

div.head: SARAPION OF THMUIS AND HIS PRAYER BOOK
div.p: A few years ago an ancient document of first rate importance for the history of Christianity in Egypt was discovered, and receivod far less notice than it deserved. This was the "Prayer Book of Bishop Sarapion" which may be termed an Egyptian Pontifical dating from the fourth century. The author is a well known personage, for this Sarapion was Bishop of Thmuis, a city of Lower Egypt, in the Delta near Lake Monzaleb. The site of its ruins is now known as Tmey-el-Amdid, about five miles east of the railway between Mansura and Abu-Kebir. The town was not far from Mendes, the chief seat, of the goat god of the old Egyptians, and the name Thmuis is thought to have been derived from Thmu, the male goat.* This Sarapion was a valued friend of two.preeminent Egyptian Ecclesiastics, Athanasius and Antony, the latter of whom bequeathed a cloak to Sarapion on his death bed. The recovery of this manuscript containing the lost work of Sarapion was not so much noticed in Egypt because it was not found there but in a monastery in Greece. The date of the writing of the treatise is somewhere between A.D. 350 and 358. It is not the only book we possess by its author, there being extant a treatise by him against the Manicheans, and several epistles.

He was, however, chiefly famous as being the recipient of five very valuable letters, from a theological point of view, addressed to him by Athanasius. The number of prayers in this series by Sarapion is thirty, and they are not intended, apparently, for use by the laity or congregation but by the minister. A curious occurrence in them is to be found in the application of a number of titles to the Divinity which appear to be founded upon similar concepts to those which are embodied in the eulogistic names given to the Ptolenmic monarchs, such as filantropos ; filoptocos ; everghetis ; and filantropia.

One of the Sarapion prayers is a petition for rain, and a similar one is to be found in the old Coptic Jacobite Church service. Thmuis, being in the Delta, lay within the region of the rains which there, in winter, are borne over the land by the northern wind off the Mediterranean, the mean rainfall at Alexandria being about eight inches. This is not the place to enter into any discussion of the theological tenets of the treatise, but one or two points of general interest may be referred to. For in- stance in Dr. G. Wordsworth's edition of Sarapion he points out that the well known phrase as to renouncing Satan and his ''pomps'' and vanities originated in the phrase of the very early renunciation which was repeated by converts, and which is first recorded in the "Canons of Hippolytus," in which they promised to renounce Satan and his "pompa" or followers (cortege). Mr. Salomon Reinach detected this fact about the same time as Dr. Wordsworth in reference to a passage in Tertullian, giving the correct meaning of "pompa." Among the ecclesiastics who appear in the hierarchy in this manuscript are "Interpreters", a necessary class of persons to render any Greek pronouncements into Coptic or vice versa. In a very early account of a visit to the Holy Land known as the "Perigrinatio Silviae" it is said that at Jerusalem the Interpreter always stood by the Bishop to interpret his allocations into Syriac, and at least one eminent Syriac ecclesiastic is known as "Theodore the Interpreter." To anyone closely acquainted with ancient Egyptian literature the 18th prayer has a very Egyptian character about it. It is termed "Prayer for one who is dead and about to be carried forth" ; it alludes to God as the "God of the spirits", also to the Gates of Hades in the plural, reminding one of the old Egyptian "Book of Gates" or "Book of Pylons" in the nether world. It also promises a resting place to the spirit "in green places" and in chambers, very similar to the formulae of the "Book of the Ani-Tuat" and especially alludes to the "going forth of the soul", which is very like the "going forth" or "coming forth" of the "Book of the Dead."

These may be mere coincidences, but the certainty of the derivation from old Egyptian sources of much of the description of the inferno in the recently-found "Apocalypse of Peter" renders it probable that we have here from Sarapion ideas which were originally in the ancient Egyptian theology.
*N.B- Ammianus Marcellinus says that in his time it was one of the four largest cities in Egypt.

div.head: THE YEMEN TROUBLE
div.p: The special correspondent of the "Times" at Beyrout sends an important message, dated July, 11th., to that journal describing the present serious condition of affairs in the Yemen, of the increasing difficulties which the Turkish Commander has to face.

That the military situation in Yemen is unsatisfactory appears clearly he says, by the fact that the most optimistic letters which have reached Damascus from the front during the past week merely express the belief that Faizi Pasha and his force will be able to hold Sanaa till the arrival of the reinforcements which were so insistently demanded by the commander of the Yemen Field Force The idea that the appearance of these reinforcements on the scene of action can have any permanent effect on the issue of the campaign is scouted in Syria, where it is believed that the Imam Yahya will, at most retire before the new forces into the mountains and thence conduct a harassing guerilla campaign till the inevitable wastage of the Turkish armies enables him to take the field with a better chance of success Moreover, it is improbable that the Turkish forces, as at present organized and equipped, can ever force their more mobile opponents to action in the open, while the rebels in their own mountains are now considered to be tactically equal, if not superior, to the Turks. The utter inefficiency of the coast blockade, or rather watch, conducted by a few superannuated gunboats and Customs craft enables the contraband trade in arms and ammunition between Yemen and Massawah, Jibuti, and other ports on the west coast of the Red Sea to be carried on with the minimum of risk. Many thousand rifles and large quantities of ammunition have been captured during the campaign, and the shooting of the insurgents is said to be far more accurate than that of the majority of the Turkish troops, whose musketry training, as a rule, begins and ends with manual exercises in the handling of an empty rifle.

The deficiency in the ammunition supply, which has caused Faizi Pasha great anxiety, is now being remedied by large indents on the reserve ammunition of the First (Constantinople) and second (Adrianople) Army Corps, but the disorganization of the transport, the utter breakdown of the under staffed and ill-equipped medical service, and the indifferent moral both of officers and men militate far more seriously against Faizi Pasha's chances than the notorious weakness of his troops in tactics and musketry. There are still numerous Syrian Moslems among the troops in Yemen, whose presence constitutes an element of weakness, though the Syrian soldiers showed remarkable powers of endurance during the siege of Sanaa in 1905. They are accused by the Turkish officers of sympathizing with and even of giving information to the rebels, and these accusations would seem to be well-founded as far the last six months scarcely any Syrian reservists or recruits have been called to the colours for service in Yemen. Outbreaks among the troops on the transports bound to and from Hodeida are becoming a regular feature of the journeys of these overcrowded and insanitary vessels. Thus, on July 4, the transport Marmara arrived here from Hodeida with 2,300 time-expired Syrian and Turkish soldiers on board. On the arrival of the transport Rear- Admiral Fayek Pasha ordered her captain to remain outside the harbour and to inform the troops that their arrears of jury, amounting to £T32,000, would be paid very shortly, and that they must, therefore, make no demonstration. The troops, however, insisted on the Marmara being brought into port, and on the following day landed en masse and made a noisy demonstration before the Defterdar's house, with the result that the arrears due to them were paid, £T25,000 in cash and the balance in "sanads" (orders on the provincial treasuries for the remission of taxes). Still more serious is the attitude of many of the officers at the front. Several very discreditable surrenders have taken place, and there is no doubt that a number of the officers of the Sanaa garrison mutinied early in June, seized the telegraph office, and telegraphed their complaints to Constantinople, threatening to surrender or abandon their posts unless their grievances were speedily remedied.

Indeed, it is difficult not to believe that the insurgents could have driven the Turkish forces to the coast six months ago, but for the mutual suspicions and jealousies of their leaders, and it is just this inability on the part of the Arabs, settled or nomad, to combine against the unpopular rule of the Turk that has prevented any extension of the rebellion beyond the Yemen province and the southern districts of Azir. The Hedjazis openly grumble at the approach of the railway, which will shorten the Syrian pilgrimage and injure the hosts of camel owners, traders, and others, who batten on the much-enduring Hadji, but as yet show no signs of supporting the heretical Zaidis of Yemen, whose Imam has claimed equality with the Sherif of Mecca. In Nejd, the warfare of the kites and crows, Ibn Saud against Ibn Rashid, continues without decisive result. Aided by a cousin and two brothers, Sultan Ibn Rashid in no wise departed from the traditions of his house when he treacherously slew his cousin the Emir Mut'ib and three of his kinsmen some eight months ago and proclaimed himself Emir of Hail. Abd el Aziz ibn Saud, Emir of Riadh, who had made truce with Mut'ib, forthwith vowed vengeance, and waged war in the desultory Bednin fashion against the usurper, defeated Sultan ibn Rashid's forces, and was himself surprised and all but captured in a night attack which stampeded his undisciplined levies. The fears of a Wahabi attack expressed by the Turkish authorities at Medina have now been dissipated. Haindu ibu Rashid, uncle of the usurping Sultan, a strong Wahabi, has, doubtless with good reason foreworn the neighbourhood of his dangerous nephew and repaired to Medina with his followers, and though many Wahabis from the various districts of Nejd have entered the holy city, their object has been to pay their respects to an influential and religious chief who openly professes neutrality. Thus far, in the long struggle of the houses, fortune has, on the whole, favoured the Beni Saud, but will this be the case when the Hejaz railway has reached Medain Salih, and the Turks, who have generally supported the Emir of Hail, are in a position to intervene effectively on his behalf t The Yemen war may last for years, but there seems to be little risk of any great combination of the Arabs of Northern and Central Arabia against the steady southward advance of the Turk.

div.head: PALESTINE EXPLORATION FUND.
div.p: In the fourteenth quarterly report on the excavation of Gezer, Mr. Stewart Macalister, MA., F.S.A., says-

Early in November of last year I landed in Palestine, and almost immediately proceeded to Constantinople to inquire into the progress of the negotiations for the new permit for the resumption of work at Gezer. While in Constantinople, I had opportunities of attempting to extend an interest in the work of the Fund, by lecturing at Robert College, and at the American College for Girls at Scutari. I have to express my acknowledgments of the friendly courtesy with which their Excellencies Hamdy and Khalil Bey received me in the magnificent museum under their control. I must also acknowledge the interest of the officials of his Majesty's Embassy, especially, Mr. Fitzmaurice, who was in charge of the negotiations. Last, but not least, I have to render my cordial thanks to the Fund's staunch friend Mr. Edwin Pears, for much help and kindness.
After finishing business in Constantinople I returned to Jerusalem, and a few days later set off for Safed- a diary of my visit there was contributed to the last Quarterly Statement. (1)

Towards the end of February I heard that the permit was shortly to be issued. Soon afterwards it was actually in my hands. A week or two had to be spent in necessary preparations and certain official routine, but as soon as possible I made my way to the mound. I am happy to report that I found it exactly as I left it, no harm having come to any of the buildings that were left open at the close of the previous permit. This is to a large extent due to Mr. Murad's friendly care and interest. It is a matter for satisfaction that Surraya Efiendi Al-Khalidi, who during the previous peimit showed himself ready to further the interests of the Fund in every way possible, consistently with a scrupulous performance of his own duties as Commissioner of the Ottoman Government, has been re-appointed to the same office.

The actual work of excavation began March 18th, and, except for a couple of days at Easter, has been continued uninterruptedly. The weather has been propitious, although hot south and east winds have been prevalent and on some days made exertion not a little laborious. I have this time made a new departure, and built a hut to take the place of the tents in which the excavating party was formerly domiciled. On all grounds-comfort, economy, stability, and security-the change has been found an improvement

It may be remembered that just at the close of the previous permit three remarkable tombs were found, which for various reasons I suggested might possibly be referable to the Philistines. I hoped that these might prove to be the outlying tombs of a cemetery, which, if it were actually Philistine, could not fail to afford results of the highest importance. The ground north, south and east of these tombs was left uncut at the end of the permit. I immediately commenced at this promising spot, and ran a trench north of the tombs to the border of the mound : nothing, however, was found in that direction. A pit was then dug to the south of these, and two more tombs of the series were there found. Excavations are now proceeding to the east, but at the moment of writing the level of the graves has not been reached. - One pit has also been dug on the Eastern Hill.

As usual, in looking for one thing, another has been discovered. The trench cut northward from the tombs was found to contain an interesting foundation, apparently that of a Canaanite palace or fortress. Beneath it was another of the very early caves which have been such a notable feature of tho mound of Gezer. The most interesting "find" from the Eastern Hill has been a small stone altar.
On the whole, however, the objects discovered during the last two months have been of an "average" character.

(1) This contribution was shortened to reduce it to the availible space, and in the process one or two errors have slipped in. I may be allowed to indicate the three principle places where misunderstanding is possible. On p. 95, line 19 for "remains, except" read remains. There is." On p. 103 in the title of the figure, for "fine" read "firm." on p.116, line 8 from the bottom, for "ruin above described" read "ruin on the hill-top"- the description reffered to not having been printed.

div.head: THE SOAP COMBINE.
div.p: A correspondent writes :-

The outburst of joy evinced by the English press at the awards in the libel actions brought by Lever Brothers and Watson & Sons against the "Daily Mail" is almost indecent in its unrestraint and passes the bounds of righteous indignation.
The motive which induced the chief proprietor of the paper to undertake the campaign against the alleged soap trust last autumn is not easily explained. It was probably a mixed one.

The various firms forming the soap combine wished to economise in their advertising departments which, through increasing competition, entailed an enormous expenditure. They also wished to be in a position to purchase raw material more cheaply, and it is now alleged that fear of losing these valuble advertisements for the various publication the Associated Press decided Lord Northcliffe in attacking the combine. It is also stated that Lord Northcliffe combated the very methods in the soap combine which he has personally introduced into journalism. He succeeded in breaking the combine but in so doing he resorted to statements which were libellous and he has been called upon to pay the penalty, which is as it should be. No one however has given him credit for a disinterested motive, a desire to safeguard the public!

The "Daily Mail" has during its career, as its circulation will show, seriously affected the sale of the morning papers sold at double the price and these papers naturally seize on this opportunity to discredit their rival before the public. Therefore in answer to their allegation concerning the motives which inspired Lord Northcliffe in his campaign against the soap trust, one would ask "Since when is Saul also among the prophets!

The people who have the leisure in which to wade through a morning paper such as the "Times" or the ''Daily Telegraph" are in the minority and the "Daily Mail" supplied a long felt want. One need not necessarily assume that people of intelligence form their political views on the lines advocated by that journal.

Many ot those pre-eminent in the field of science and literature have contributed articles to the "Daily Mail" and, while one regrets the strain of yellow journalism which, through its news columns, it has introduced into England, one takes the perfervid outburst of Its rivals on this occasion, with the proverbial pinch of salt.

div.head: NATIONALISTS
div.p: It is no doubt fellow-feeling says the "Globe" which has made certain of the Irish Nationalist politicians display so great an interest in the movements of the Indian agitators. It is all one to them if they embarrass the Government of the Empire in England or Asia, or, as they proved last year in discussing the Denshawi outrages, in Egypt, and a few years ago, in South Afriea. All is grist that comes to their mill. And similarly, it is not surprising that the disloyal section of the Indian vernacular Press keeps itself and his readers well informed as to the program of the Sinn Fein League in Ireland, and identifies the aims of the latter with the Swadeshi and the boycott in Bengal. The seditions have a keen eye for their friends all over the world, and they realise that an unacknowledged alliance more than doubles their power. But the exposure of such tactics ought to undeceive some of those Radical sympathisers in this country as to the real character of the people with whom they are half-inclined to express sympathy. Unless they wish Ireland to be ruled by a tyrannical association of men who use, a preposterous sham Gaelic propaganda to impotence has so often been proved through its subjugation by the wild tribe of the Himalayas, they will cease to give a passive support to sedition, from whatever quarter it may come. It is one thing to recognise legitimate grievances: it is very different when such grievances are manufactured for ulterior aims.

div.head: A BROKEN-DOWN SYSTEM.
div.p: This is a condition (or disease) to which doctors give many names, but which few of them really understand. It it simply weakness—a break-down, as it were, of the vital forces that sustain the system. No matter what may be its causes (for they are almost numberless), its symptoms are much the same; the more prominent being sleeplessness, sense of prostration or weariness, depression of spirits and want of energy for all the ordinary affairs of life. Now, what alone is absolutely essential in all such cases is increased vitality—vigour--
